intro: Sinapis cheiranthos var. genuina, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mustard, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, branching stems and narrow, pinnately lobed leaves. Its flowers are usually yellow or pale yellow, and it blooms from spring to early summer. This species is often found in disturbed soils and is used in phytoremediation due to its ability to accumulate heavy metals.
